Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Controls over C sequestration: physiology vs. physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the global carbon cycle is a central issue facing ecosystem science because of carbon dioxide's (CO2) role in the greenhouse effect and climate change. One of the main stores of organic carbon on Earth is in soil, which contains more organic carbon than all the plants growing upon it. This project aims to better understand C-sequestration by evaluating the physical processes (diffusion & desorption) that regulate microorganisms' access to C, and how they use that C to make enzymes to acquire additional resources, and modify their immediate environment. A major focus of the work will be to explore how these processes are influenced by soil moisture and drought. The research will be done at the Sedgwick Reserve in California, and will use a combination of field experiments to manipulate plant inputs of fresh carbon and water inputs, laboratory studies to evaluate specific mechanisms involved in controlling the processes, and mathematical modeling to relate these fine-scale mechanisms to larger-scale dynamics.

This project will help train interdisciplinary graduate student researchers, and will involve undergraduate students, bringing them into the research environment. For public outreach, the project will rely on Sedgwick Reserve?s center for public education. The investigators have developed presentations about soils, soil research, and their importance to society. They will update these with information from this project, and work with the docents to use in their educational programs. Members of the research team will continue their activities mentoring K-12 students with programs such as their "Soil's Alive!" demonstration of soil ecology for 10th graders from the local Santa Ynez Valley Union High School District,

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon sequestration has become a critical issue for scientists, land managers, and lawmakers, but major questions remain as to what regulates the fate of C in soils. Microbes decompose plant litter and soil C, and so much research has naturally focused on the physiology of breakdown. However, on the time scales relevant for sequestration—decades, not days—few molecules are so recalcitrant that microbes cannot metabolize them if they have access. The critical issues in understanding long-term C-sequestration may be what controls whether microbes get access to that C and what they do with it—its fate. This leads to the central ideas that drove this research.

First, the relationships among plant inputs, microbial access, and microbial allocation determine the composition and turnover of soil organic matter pools and how they respond to a changing climate: will C be stored or not? Second, as soils dry, soil patches become disconnected from each other, leaving components of the system separated and unable to interact. This is a common phenomenon as soils dry, and likely dominates the functioning of soils in arid, semi-arid, and Mediterranean grasslands. As a result of this hydrological breakdown, dry soils don’t just process materials slower than moist soils, but they do so differently. During the hot dry summer, when plants are dead and it seems like soil microbes should be dying, microbial biomass in the soil actually increases. Why? Where does the carbon come from? We hypothesized that the previous winter’s dead grass roots which are then broken down by enzymes that microbes produce and release into the environment. We also hypothesized that the longer the dry period, the more of the dry season products would accumulate. To test these ideas, we set up a field experiment where we removed plants and used watering and rain-out shelters to alter the length of the summer dry season. We predicted that removing plants would starve the summer microbial community and reduce the pools of available resources, the biomass of microbes, and the supply of materials at the beginning of the following winter growing season.

We were surprised that our hypothesis was wrong! Removing plants had only limited effects on soil processes. Doing so reduced C-fluxes during the summer, quite possibly as a loss of CO2 production from the surface litter itself, and caused the largest soil aggregates to fragment slightly, becoming smaller. But even two years of completely removing plants had little influence on the amount of microbes, their production of extracellular materials, or even on how much they respire during the first part of the following growing season. There is so much mineral-associated organic matter that it is able to fuel microbial systems for several years even without fresh inputs. A major finding was that dry season processes are regulated much more by mineral interactions than by biological ones. Even the response to rewetting seemed to be regulated by the ability of clays to restabilize carbon—in competition with microbial uptake—that was mobilized by rewetting.

We have developed a new generation of simulation models to capture these physical processes of sorption, diffusion, and mass transport, and to integrate them with biological activities to understand and predict how drought and dry/wet cycles will affect ecosystems under conditions of changing climate, and so to understand how shifting patters of rainfall will affect long-term carbon storage and stabilization in soil. 

As part of this project, we have worked with a number of UCSB undergraduates, docents at the Sedgwick reserve, a local vinyard (SeaSmoke) to explore using extracellular polysaccharides to enhance prodcutivity under reduced water supply, and with field classes from California Polytechnic State University.
